title: Expository Writing — Integrating Research into a Feature Article
description: Students apply their research and writing skills to create a feature article on a space exploration or technology topic. They learn the conventions of journalistic feature writing, integrate multiple sources, and write for a specific audience.
instructions:
1. Distinguish between hard news articles and feature articles.
2. Analyze published feature articles: What makes them engaging?
3. Discuss feature article structure: hook, nut graph, body with anecdotes and data, kicker ending.
4. Introduce the 'nut graph' — the paragraph that tells the reader why this story matters NOW.
5. Model integrating research sources into journalistic writing.
6. Discuss writing for audience: adjust tone, vocabulary, and detail for your reader.
7. Students choose a topic and begin drafting their feature article.
8. Practice including direct quotes from sources.
9. Peer review focusing on engagement and information balance.
10. Revise for clarity, accuracy, and voice.

slides.heading: Feature Article Writing
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure into writing feature articles. It tells us we're going to learn how to write stories that aren't just about "what happened" but are super engaging and use cool research to tell us "why it matters." Think of it like being a detective, but instead of solving a crime, you're uncovering an interesting story that people will want to read.

slides.setup_instructions: Select 2-3 engaging feature articles at appropriate reading level on science or technology topics. Print the feature article structure guide. Have students' research notes from previous lessons available.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this slide is our "mission control" for getting started. We've got some examples of awesome feature articles that are already written – these are like our inspiration and maps. We also have a guide that breaks down the secret recipe for a feature article, your own research notes from last time, and of course, some paper and pencils for writing and highlighters to mark up those cool examples.

slides.text: A feature article goes deeper than news. While a news article reports WHAT happened, a feature explores WHY it matters, HOW it affects people, and WHAT it means. Features use storytelling techniques — anecdotes, vivid details, and compelling characters — alongside facts and data.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about understanding what makes a feature article different from a regular news report. While news just tells you the facts, a feature article pulls you in with stories, details, and explanations about *why* something is important and how it affects us. It’s like the difference between someone just telling you it rained, and someone telling you about the beautiful rainbow that appeared after the rain and how it made their day.

slides.text: Feature structure: HOOK — an engaging opening (anecdote, scene, surprising fact). NUT GRAPH — the paragraph that explains why this story matters and what the article will cover. BODY — alternating between anecdotes/stories and data/analysis. KICKER — a memorable ending that resonates.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's a look at the building blocks of a great feature article. You start with a "hook" to grab the reader's attention, like a cool story or a surprising fact. Then comes the "nut graph," which is super important because it tells everyone why they should keep reading. The "body" is where you mix in more stories and interesting facts, and finally, the "kicker" is a strong ending that leaves a lasting impression.

slides.text: The nut graph is unique to journalism. It answers the reader's question: 'Why should I care about this?' Example: After a hook about a grandmother using GPS to find her way, the nut graph might say: 'GPS technology, born in the Cold War space race, now guides 4 billion smartphone users daily.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide focuses on the "nut graph," which is like the heart of your article. It’s the paragraph that answers the reader's question: "Why should I spend my time reading this?" For example, if you started with a fun story about a dog learning a new trick, the nut graph would explain how that trick relates to bigger things like animal training science or even how pets help people.

slides.text: Balance storytelling and information. Too many facts and the article is boring. Too many stories and it lacks substance. The best features weave between the two: a personal anecdote followed by data that gives it context, then another story that brings the data to life.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a really key idea: you need to find the sweet spot between telling stories and sharing facts. If you only use facts, your article might sound like a textbook and put people to sleep. But if you only tell stories without any facts, it might not feel very informative. The best feature articles blend them together, like having a personal story followed by some cool data that explains it even better.

slides.prompt: Write a feature article (500-700 words) on a space or technology topic. Include: (1) An engaging hook that draws the reader in. (2) A nut graph explaining why this topic matters today. (3) At least 3 body paragraphs alternating between anecdotes/stories and data/analysis. (4) At least 2 properly cited sources. (5) A memorable kicker ending. Choose your topic: The future of Mars exploration, how satellites changed daily life, women in space history, or a technology spinoff that changed the world.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is where you get to be the author! You'll pick one of those space or tech topics and start writing your own feature article. Remember to include that attention-grabbing hook, the important nut graph explaining why your topic matters, at least three body paragraphs that mix stories and facts, and a strong ending. Make sure to use information from at least two sources and cite them properly.

slides.text: Feature writing combines the best of storytelling and research. It informs while it entertains, and it makes complex topics accessible to general audiences. This is the kind of writing that appears in magazines, long-form journalism, and the best online content.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student write a feature article with proper structure (hook, nut graph, body, kicker), integrate research with storytelling, and cite sources appropriately?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide reminds us that feature writing is awesome because it teaches and entertains at the same time. You've learned how to take interesting research and turn it into a story that people will actually enjoy reading, kind of like how magazines do it. The big check is to see if you can put all those pieces together – the hook, the nut graph, the body, and the ending – and use your research to make your story shine.

parent_notes: Feature article writing is one of the most versatile writing skills because it combines research, storytelling, and audience awareness. Many students find this more engaging than traditional essay writing because the journalistic style allows for creativity within a clear structure. The nut graph concept — explaining why a story matters NOW — develops the skill of connecting information to relevance. If your child enjoys this, explore student journalism opportunities. Consider submitting their best feature article to a school newsletter or local publication.

title: Percentages and Proportional Reasoning — Solving Real Problems
description: Students synthesize their percentage skills by solving complex, multi-step real-world problems requiring proportional reasoning. They work with scale drawings, unit rates, and proportions, building toward algebraic thinking with ratio and percent relationships.
instructions:
1. Review percent change, discounts, and tax from previous weeks.
2. Introduce proportional reasoning: if 3 apples cost $2, how much do 12 apples cost?
3. Set up and solve proportions using cross-multiplication.
4. Apply proportions to scale drawings and maps.
5. Calculate unit rates and use them for comparison shopping.
6. Solve multi-step problems combining percentages and proportions.
7. Work with Space Race data: scale model calculations, fuel consumption rates.
8. Students create and solve their own multi-step percentage and proportion problems.
9. Challenge problems requiring creative application of multiple skills.
10. Reflect on how proportional reasoning connects to all previous math topics.

slides.heading: Proportional Reasoning
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure today, saying we're going to get really good at "Proportional Reasoning" and use it to solve tricky problems we see in the real world. Think of it as setting the stage for some cool math detective work.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare multi-step problem worksheets with real-world contexts. Print scale drawing examples. Create proportion solving reference cards showing the cross-multiplication method.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is showing us all the tools we'll need for our math mission. We've got a reference card to help us remember how to solve proportions, examples of scale drawings to look at, a calculator for when numbers get big, graph paper and rulers for drawing, worksheets with problems, and pencils to write with. Make sure you have all these things ready to go, maybe ask a grown-up to help you gather them.

slides.text: A proportion says two ratios are equal: 3/2 = 12/x. Cross-multiply to solve: 3x = 24, so x = 8. This technique works for any proportion problem. If a map scale is 1 inch = 50 miles and two cities are 3.5 inches apart, the real distance is: 1/50 = 3.5/x, so x = 175 miles.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about proportions, which are just a way of saying two ratios are equal – like if you know 3 apples cost $2, you can figure out how much 12 apples would cost without guessing. The slide shows you how to "cross-multiply" to solve for the missing number, like finding out how many miles are on a map if you know the scale.

slides.text: Unit rates help you compare: Store A sells 6 muffins for $9 ($1.50 each). Store B sells 4 for $5 ($1.25 each). The unit rate reveals that Store B is cheaper per muffin. Unit rates turn complex comparisons into simple ones.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here, we're learning about "unit rates," which are super handy for comparing things. Imagine you're at the store and see two different sizes of your favorite snack – the unit rate tells you the price for *one* single item, so you can easily see which one is the better deal.

slides.text: Scale models use proportions: The Saturn V rocket was 363 feet tall. A 1:100 scale model would be 3.63 feet (about 43.5 inches). To find any dimension on the model, divide the real dimension by the scale factor. Engineers and architects use this daily.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide explains how proportions are used for "scale models," like building a mini version of a giant rocket. If you know how big the real thing is and the scale you're using (like 1 inch on the model equals 100 inches in real life), you can figure out exactly how big your model should be.

slides.text: Multi-step challenge: A store has a 20% off sale. You buy 3 items at $25, $40, and $15. Calculate the discount on each, find the sale price, add 8% tax, and determine if you can afford it all with $75. Each step uses skills you have mastered — now combine them fluently.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for a challenge! This step combines everything we've learned, like figuring out discounts and sales tax. You'll take a bunch of items, calculate the sale price after a percentage off, then add on tax, and finally check if you have enough money to buy it all.

slides.prompt: Solve these multi-step problems: (1) A recipe serves 4 people and uses 2.5 cups of flour. How much flour for 10 people? If flour costs $0.40 per cup, what is the flour cost for 10 people? (2) On a map where 1 cm = 25 km, a hiking trail measures 7.2 cm. If you hike at 4 km/hour, how long will the trail take? (3) Build a scale model: The International Space Station is 357 feet long and 240 feet wide. Draw a scale model on graph paper using a scale of 1 square = 15 feet. How many squares long and wide is your model? (4) Create your own multi-step problem involving at least 2 different percentage/proportion skills.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be the math creator! You'll solve some problems that mix and match skills, like figuring out ingredients for a bigger recipe or how long a hike will take based on a map scale. Then, the really fun part is making up your *own* problem that uses percentages and proportions.

slides.text: Proportional reasoning connects percentages, fractions, ratios, and algebra. It is the thread running through all of your math work this quarter. When you can set up and solve proportions fluently, you have a tool that works in science, cooking, finance, engineering, and art.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student set up and solve proportions using cross-multiplication, calculate unit rates, work with scale drawings, and solve multi-step problems combining percentages and proportions?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the wrap-up, telling us how proportional reasoning is like a secret code that connects all the math we've done, from fractions to algebra. It's a powerful tool that helps people in tons of jobs, from designing buildings to cooking delicious meals.

parent_notes: Proportional reasoning is consistently identified as the most important mathematical concept for middle school success. It connects fractions, percentages, ratios, and algebra into a coherent framework. The scale model activity is particularly engaging and connects to engineering and architecture. Practice at home with real situations: doubling or halving recipes, calculating travel times from map distances, comparing unit prices at the grocery store. If your child can fluently set up and solve proportions, they have the mathematical foundation for success in pre-algebra and beyond.

title: The Space Shuttle Era and the International Space Station
description: Students examine how space exploration evolved from competition to cooperation. They study the Space Shuttle program, the construction of the International Space Station, and how former rivals became partners in exploring space together.
instructions:
1. Recap the Space Race: from competition to cooperation.
2. Discuss the Apollo-Soyuz mission (1975) as the first US-Soviet joint space mission.
3. Introduce the Space Shuttle program (1981-2011): the first reusable spacecraft.
4. Examine the Shuttle's achievements and tragedies (Challenger 1986, Columbia 2003).
5. Study the International Space Station: 15 nations building a home in space.
6. Discuss what astronauts do on the ISS: science experiments, Earth observation, technology testing.
7. Examine how cooperation replaced competition in space.
8. Discuss the new Space Race: private companies (SpaceX, Blue Origin) and new nations.
9. Create a timeline of post-Apollo space exploration.
10. Debate: Should space exploration be a government or private enterprise?

slides.heading: Beyond Apollo
slides.subheading: The Space Shuttle, ISS, and International Cooperation
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for a new chapter in our space story. It's called "Beyond Apollo," and it's going to tell us all about what happened after the moon landings, focusing on the Space Shuttle, that giant Space Station we built, and how countries started working together instead of against each other in space.

slides.setup_instructions: Print photographs of the Space Shuttle, ISS construction, and international crews. Prepare information about modern space companies. Have timeline templates ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is telling us what we'll need for the activities. We've got pictures of the Space Shuttle and the International Space Station, some info on that first handshake mission between the US and Soviet Union, a template for making a timeline, facts about the new space companies, and then your art supplies: colored markers and pencils. Go grab all these things with a grown-up so we're ready to go!

slides.text: After Apollo, the Space Race cooled. In 1975, American astronauts and Soviet cosmonauts met in orbit for the Apollo-Soyuz mission — shaking hands in space. Former enemies became partners. This shift from competition to cooperation defined the next era of space exploration.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step explains how things changed after the moon missions. Remember the Space Race between the US and the Soviet Union? Well, this shows how it started to become less about beating each other and more about working together, starting with that cool Apollo-Soyuz mission where astronauts from both countries actually met and worked together in space.

slides.text: The Space Shuttle (1981-2011) was revolutionary: the first reusable spacecraft. It launched satellites, carried the Hubble Space Telescope, and built the ISS. But it also saw tragedy: Challenger exploded 73 seconds after launch in 1986, killing all 7 crew including teacher Christa McAuliffe. Columbia disintegrated on reentry in 2003, killing 7 more.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's the scoop on the Space Shuttle, which was like a flying truck for space from 1981 to 2011. It was amazing because it could fly back to Earth and be used again, and it did tons of important jobs like putting satellites into orbit and helping build the International Space Station, but it also had some really sad moments with accidents like the Challenger and Columbia disasters.

slides.text: The International Space Station is the largest structure humans have ever built in space: the size of a football field, orbiting 250 miles above Earth. Fifteen nations contributed to its construction. Crews from the US, Russia, Japan, Europe, and Canada live and work together continuously since November 2000.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide shows us the International Space Station, which is this huge home for astronauts that's bigger than a football field and orbits way above us. It’s super cool because it wasn't built by just one country, but by fifteen different nations working together, and people have been living and working there non-stop since the year 2000.

slides.text: Today, a new Space Race is emerging — but this time, private companies lead alongside governments. SpaceX (Elon Musk) has dramatically reduced launch costs. Blue Origin (Jeff Bezos) and Virgin Galactic (Richard Branson) pursue space tourism. China and India have grown into major space powers. The next chapter is being written now.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready, because this slide is talking about a brand new kind of Space Race! It's not just countries competing anymore; now, private companies like SpaceX and Blue Origin are building rockets and even flying people to space, and countries like China and India are becoming big players too.

slides.prompt: Complete three tasks: (1) Create a post-Apollo timeline from 1975 to present, marking at least 10 key events: Apollo-Soyuz, Shuttle first flight, Challenger, Hubble launch, ISS construction begins, Columbia, Shuttle retirement, SpaceX milestones, and recent events. (2) Compare the old Space Race (US vs. USSR) with the new space competition (governments and companies). Create a Venn diagram showing similarities and differences. (3) Write a position paper: Should space exploration be led by governments (public funding, shared benefits) or private companies (innovation, efficiency)? Support your position with at least 3 arguments.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is where you get to be the historian and scientist! You'll create a timeline of important space events since 1975, then compare the old Space Race with the new one using a Venn diagram, and finally, you'll write your opinion on whether governments or private companies should be in charge of space exploration, giving reasons for your choice.

slides.text: Space exploration has evolved from a two-nation race into a global, public-private endeavor. The ISS proves that international cooperation can achieve what no single nation can alone. The question for your generation: Where will humanity go next — Mars? Asteroids? Beyond?
slides.mastery_check: Can the student trace the evolution of space exploration from competition to cooperation, evaluate the roles of governments and private companies, and construct supported arguments about space exploration policy?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide wraps up our journey by reminding us how space exploration has changed from a competition between two countries into a huge team effort involving lots of nations and even private companies. It leaves us thinking about the future and where we might explore next, like Mars or even farther!

parent_notes: This lesson brings space history into the present, making it relevant and forward-looking. The shift from competition to cooperation is an important lesson about international relations. The Space Shuttle tragedies (Challenger and Columbia) should be handled sensitively but honestly — they are part of the story of human courage and risk. The debate about public vs. private space exploration connects to broader questions about the role of government and the private sector. Follow current space news together to keep the connection alive.

title: Mapping Ocean Changes — Coral Bleaching and Sea Level Rise
description: Students map the geographic distribution of coral bleaching events and sea level rise impacts. They analyze the spatial patterns of ocean warming, identify vulnerable coastal communities, and create maps showing projected changes in marine environments.
instructions:
1. Review ocean ecosystems and coral reef biodiversity from previous science lessons.
2. Explain coral bleaching: what causes it and why it matters.
3. Map global coral bleaching events from recent years.
4. Identify the geographic pattern: bleaching correlates with ocean temperature anomalies.
5. Examine sea level rise projections for major coastal cities.
6. Map the world's most vulnerable coastal populations.
7. Discuss small island developing states and their existential threat from sea level rise.
8. Students create a dual-theme ocean change map.
9. Calculate the potential displacement of coastal populations.
10. Discuss geographic strategies for adaptation: sea walls, managed retreat, restoration.

slides.heading: Mapping Ocean Changes
slides.subheading: Coral Bleaching and Sea Level Rise
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just introducing what we're going to learn about today: how our oceans are changing, specifically with coral reefs getting sick (that's bleaching) and the water levels going up. Think of it like a weather report, but for the whole ocean, and it's showing us some serious stuff that's happening.

slides.setup_instructions: Print world ocean maps with coral reef locations marked. Prepare coral bleaching data showing affected areas and dates. Print sea level rise projection maps. Gather coastal population data for major cities.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this slide is showing us all the stuff we'll need to do our mapping project. We've got a big map of the world's oceans, some special maps that show where coral bleaching has happened and where the sea level is rising, colored pencils to mark things up, a calculator for some figuring, and data about who lives near the coast. Make sure you have all these things ready to go, and ask a grown-up to help you print them out if you need to.

slides.text: Coral reefs are dying. When ocean temperatures rise just 1-2 degrees C above normal, corals expel their symbiotic algae and turn white — this is bleaching. If temperatures do not return to normal quickly, the coral dies. The Great Barrier Reef has experienced mass bleaching events in 2016, 2017, 2020, and 2022.
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is explaining what coral bleaching is. Imagine corals are like tiny animals that have little algae friends living inside them, and these algae give them food and their color. When the water gets too hot, even just a little bit, the corals get stressed and kick out their algae friends, turning totally white. If the water doesn't cool down fast enough, those corals can die, which is a huge problem for the ocean.

slides.text: Map the bleaching pattern: events cluster in tropical waters between 30 degrees N and 30 degrees S latitude. The worst bleaching correlates with El Nino events, which raise Pacific Ocean temperatures. As global temperatures rise, bleaching is becoming more frequent and severe.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to look at *where* this bleaching is happening. The slide says it's mostly in the warmer parts of the ocean, between the middle of the Earth and the top or bottom. It also mentions that when the ocean gets warmer because of something called El Nino, the bleaching gets worse. So, basically, as the whole planet gets warmer, this coral bleaching problem is happening more and more often.

slides.text: Sea level rise threatens 680 million people living in low-lying coastal zones. Some projections: at 1 meter rise, much of Miami, Bangladesh's coast, and Pacific island nations are flooded. Jakarta, the capital of Indonesia, is already sinking and relocating to a new capital city.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is talking about how the sea level rising is a big deal for people living near the ocean. It says millions of people could be flooded if the water goes up even a little bit, and it gives examples like parts of Florida, a country called Bangladesh, and islands in the Pacific Ocean. It even mentions that a big city in Indonesia is already sinking so much they're building a whole new one!

slides.text: Geographic adaptation strategies: (1) SEA WALLS and barriers (like the Netherlands). (2) MANAGED RETREAT — moving communities away from the coast. (3) ECOSYSTEM RESTORATION — rebuilding mangroves and reefs that buffer against storms and erosion. Each strategy has tradeoffs of cost, effectiveness, and fairness.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here we're looking at different ways people are trying to protect coastlines from rising seas. One way is building big walls, like they do in some countries. Another is moving people and buildings away from the shore, which is called managed retreat. And a third way is to help nature fight back by rebuilding things like mangrove trees and coral reefs, which act like natural barriers against big waves and storms.

slides.prompt: Create a dual-theme ocean change map: (1) On a world ocean map, mark areas of major coral bleaching events (use warm colors: yellow for mild, orange for moderate, red for severe). (2) On the same map, shade coastal areas vulnerable to sea level rise (use blue hatching). (3) Mark 5 specific cities or nations most at risk with population data. (4) Add a comprehensive legend. (5) Write an analysis paragraph: What geographic patterns do you see? Which regions face BOTH coral bleaching AND sea level rise? Why are the most vulnerable nations often the least responsible for climate change?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be the mapmaker! You'll take your world ocean map and use warm colors to show where the coral bleaching is bad, and then use blue lines to mark areas that might flood from rising seas. You also need to point out five specific places that are really in danger and then write down what you notice from looking at your map, like if any places have both problems, and think about why that's not fair.

slides.text: Ocean changes are among the most visible and urgent effects of climate change. Coral reefs and coastal communities are on the front lines. Your maps show that the nations most affected are often those that contributed least to the problem — this raises profound questions about justice and responsibility.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student map coral bleaching and sea level rise impacts, identify geographic patterns, analyze the relationship between vulnerability and responsibility, and evaluate adaptation strategies?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide is reminding us that what's happening to our oceans is a big sign that our planet is changing, and it's happening fast. It highlights that the places getting hit the hardest by things like coral bleaching and sea level rise are often the places that didn't cause the problem in the first place, which makes us think about fairness and who needs to help fix it.

parent_notes: Ocean changes are visually dramatic and emotionally compelling. The coral bleaching images are striking and make the science tangible. The justice dimension (least responsible nations suffering most) connects to social studies themes about equity. If your family lives near a coast, discuss local sea level rise projections. If not, explore virtual reef tours to see the beauty of healthy coral reefs. The dual-theme mapping activity develops the ability to analyze multiple geographic patterns simultaneously — a sophisticated skill.

title: Esperanza Rising — Chapters 9-11: Strikes, Solidarity, and Sacrifice
description: Students read through the labor conflict chapters where Esperanza confronts questions of solidarity, justice, and sacrifice. These chapters explore the workers' strike, Esperanza's internal conflict, and the tension between survival and standing up for what is right.
instructions:
1. Recap Chapters 5-8: Esperanza's adjustment to camp life and growing awareness.
2. Read Chapters 9-11 aloud, pausing at moments of tension and decision.
3. Discuss the workers' strike: What are the laborers demanding and why?
4. Analyze Esperanza's internal conflict: She fears the strike will cost her family their jobs.
5. Examine Marta's perspective: Why does she believe the strike is necessary?
6. Discuss the theme of solidarity: When is it right to sacrifice personal security for collective justice?
7. Compare the farm workers' struggle to the civil rights movements studied earlier.
8. Track how Mama's illness adds urgency to Esperanza's decisions.
9. Update character webs and symbol trackers.
10. Write a dialogue between Esperanza and Marta expressing their different views.
materials_needed: Esperanza Rising by Pam Munoz Ryan

slides.heading: Esperanza Rising
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this first slide is just letting us know what we're diving into for the next few chapters of "Esperanza Rising." We're going to be looking at a really intense part of the story where the workers go on strike, and Esperanza has to deal with tough choices about standing together with others or protecting her own family. It's all about fairness, what people are willing to give up for what they believe in, and how hard that can be.

items: Esperanza Rising by Pam Munoz Ryan
slides.setup_instructions: Have novels bookmarked at Chapter 9. Distribute character webs and symbol trackers from previous sessions. Prepare for discussion of labor rights and social justice themes.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like our toolkit for the reading session. We've got the "Esperanza Rising" book itself, of course, and then a reading journal where we can jot down our thoughts. The character web is a chart we use to keep track of who's who and what they're about, and the symbol tracker is for noting down important objects or ideas that mean something more. Make sure you have your book open to chapter 9, and if you need to grab your journal, web, or tracker, go ahead and get those now.

slides.text: The workers in the camp face terrible conditions: low wages, poor housing, no job security. Marta and other workers organize a strike — refusing to work until conditions improve. But Esperanza and her family are terrified of losing their jobs. This creates a wrenching conflict.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, right now, we're learning about why the workers decide to go on strike. Imagine working really hard but not getting paid enough to even live properly, with no guarantee you'll have a job tomorrow. That's what's happening to the farm workers. Marta and others are saying, "Enough is enough!" and they're all going to stop working to demand better conditions. But Esperanza is worried because if the workers strike, her family might not have any money coming in, which is super scary, especially with her mom being sick.

slides.text: Read Chapters 9-11. Esperanza is caught between two truths: the workers deserve better treatment, AND her family cannot survive without income, especially with Mama sick. Neither side is wrong. This is what makes the conflict so powerful — there are no easy answers.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, we need to read chapters 9 through 11. As we read, pay close attention to Esperanza. She's stuck in the middle, seeing that the workers have a really good reason to strike because things are unfair, but also knowing that her family desperately needs the money from their jobs to survive. It’s a really tough spot to be in because there isn’t a clear right or wrong answer for everyone involved, and that’s what makes this part of the story so powerful.

slides.text: Marta believes that collective action is the only way to improve conditions. She asks: 'If not now, when? If not us, who?' Compare this to the civil rights leaders we studied. The strategies are similar: boycotts, strikes, and organized resistance against unjust systems.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide highlights Marta's perspective on the strike. Marta feels like the only way to make things better is for everyone to stick together and refuse to work until the bosses treat them fairly, asking questions like "If we don't do this now, when will it happen?" and "If we don't stand up, who will?" This is actually pretty similar to what leaders in the Civil Rights Movement did, using big actions like boycotts and protests to fight against unfair rules.

slides.text: Mama's illness raises the stakes. Esperanza needs money for medicine. If she strikes, she loses income. If she does not strike, she crosses the picket line. Ryan forces us to feel the impossible choices that real people face when justice conflicts with survival.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here, we see how Mama’s illness makes everything even more complicated for Esperanza. She absolutely needs money for medicine, which means she needs her job. But if she keeps working while everyone else is striking, she’ll be going against the other workers and potentially causing problems. This part of the story really shows how people sometimes have to make incredibly difficult choices when what they need to survive clashes with doing what feels morally right.

slides.prompt: Complete three tasks: (1) Update your character web: Add Marta and note the conflict between her and Esperanza. What does each character value most? (2) Write a dialogue (1 full page) between Esperanza and Marta where each explains her position on the strike. Both must present compelling arguments. Neither should be portrayed as purely right or wrong. (3) Journal reflection: Connect this story to the civil rights movement. How are the farm workers' struggles similar to the struggles of African Americans in the 1950s-60s? What strategies do they share?
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this is where you get to do some work! First, update your character web by adding Marta and thinking about what she and Esperanza want most right now, especially with this strike happening. Then, write a full page where Esperanza and Marta talk about the strike – each needs to explain why they feel the way they do, and neither should sound completely wrong. Finally, in your journal, compare what these farm workers are going through to the Civil Rights Movement we studied; think about how their struggles and the ways they fought back are alike.

slides.text: The strike chapters force us to wrestle with real moral complexity. When survival and justice conflict, there are no easy answers. Great literature does not give us simple lessons — it asks us to think deeply about difficult questions. Esperanza is growing through this struggle.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student analyze multiple perspectives in a conflict, connect the novel's themes to historical labor and civil rights movements, and write balanced dialogue representing competing viewpoints?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last part is a reminder that these chapters are all about tough decisions and figuring out what's most important when things are really hard. There aren't always easy answers in life, and good stories often make us think about those complicated situations, just like Esperanza is having to do. You’ve done a great job working through these challenging ideas and seeing how Esperanza is growing because of them.

parent_notes: These chapters deal with labor rights, strikes, and moral complexity. The key educational value is that Esperanza Rising refuses to simplify the conflict — both Esperanza and Marta have valid perspectives. This teaches children that ethical dilemmas rarely have clear-cut answers. The connection to civil rights movements is natural and deepens understanding of both topics. Discuss with your child: Have you ever been in a situation where doing the right thing might cost you something? How did you decide? Cesar Chavez and the United Farm Workers movement provides real historical context for this fictional story.

title: Advanced Vocabulary — Context Clues and Dictionary Skills
description: Students master advanced strategies for determining word meanings through context clues when root analysis alone is insufficient. They learn to use multiple types of context clues, practice efficient dictionary use, and develop strategies for academic reading across disciplines.
instructions:
1. Review root analysis as the primary vocabulary strategy.
2. Introduce context clue types: definition, synonym, antonym, example, and inference.
3. Practice identifying which type of context clue is present in sample sentences.
4. Discuss when root analysis is insufficient and context clues become essential.
5. Model efficient dictionary use: guide words, multiple definitions, choosing the right one.
6. Practice reading academic passages with unfamiliar vocabulary.
7. Apply a multi-step vocabulary strategy: root analysis first, context clues second, dictionary third.
8. Students practice with passages from science, history, and literature.
9. Create a personal vocabulary log with words, strategies used, and definitions.
10. Quiz: decode 10 challenging words using the multi-step strategy.

slides.heading: Context Clues and Dictionary Skills
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure into becoming word wizards! It's introducing us to some super cool ways to figure out what tricky words mean when we're reading, especially in harder books. Think of it as unlocking a secret code for awesome vocabulary.

slides.setup_instructions: Select academic passages from science, history, and literature with challenging vocabulary. Prepare a context clue reference chart with the five types and examples. Have dictionaries available.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is showing us all the gear we'll need for our word-hunting mission. We've got reading passages – those are like treasure maps filled with challenging words, and we'll also use a context clue chart, which is like a cheat sheet with different ways to figure out meanings, a dictionary for looking up words, and a special notebook to write down our discoveries. Make sure you have all these things ready to go, maybe ask a grown-up to help you find them!

slides.text: Your vocabulary toolkit has three tools: (1) ROOT ANALYSIS — break the word into parts. (2) CONTEXT CLUES — use surrounding words and sentences. (3) DICTIONARY — look it up. Use them in this order: roots first (fastest), context second (usually available), dictionary third (most accurate but slowest).
slides.mascot_explanation: So, this step is like getting our main strategy for tackling new words. Imagine you have a special toolbox with three tools: first, you try breaking the word apart into its smaller root parts, which is super fast. If that doesn't quite work, you use your second tool: the words around it, called context clues. And if you're still stuck, your third tool is the dictionary, which is the most accurate but takes a little longer.

slides.text: Five types of context clues: DEFINITION — the text defines the word ('Entomology, the study of insects, is fascinating'). SYNONYM — a similar word nearby ('The arid, dry landscape'). ANTONYM — an opposite word ('Unlike the gregarious children, the shy boy sat alone'). EXAMPLE — specific instances help define it. INFERENCE — the overall context suggests the meaning.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're diving into our second tool: context clues! This slide breaks down five different ways the words around a new word can help you guess its meaning. It could be that the sentence actually tells you what the word means, gives you a word that means the same thing, uses a word that means the opposite, or gives you examples to help you understand. It's like having little hints all over the page!

slides.text: The hardest type is INFERENCE: you must figure out the meaning from the overall passage. 'The pernicious effects of the chemical were not immediately apparent, but over years, the ecosystem deteriorated.' From 'not immediately apparent' and 'deteriorated,' we infer that 'pernicious' means harmful in a gradual, hidden way.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is focusing on the trickiest type of context clue, called inference. It means you have to use your detective skills to figure out the meaning from the overall feeling or information in the sentence or paragraph, instead of a direct hint. Like in the example, you have to put together that something bad happened over time to understand the meaning of that big word.

slides.text: Dictionary skills: When a word has multiple definitions, read ALL of them and choose the one that fits the context. 'Light' has over 20 definitions! The sentence 'His light touch on the piano keys produced a gentle melody' requires definition #7 (soft, not heavy) not #1 (visible radiation).
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is all about using our dictionary like a pro! When you look up a word, it might have a bunch of different meanings, right? This slide teaches you to read all of them and pick the *exact* one that makes sense for the sentence you're reading, just like choosing the right key for a specific lock.

slides.prompt: Read three academic passages (one science, one history, one literature). For each passage: (1) Underline every unfamiliar word. (2) Try root analysis first — write what the roots suggest. (3) Use context clues to refine your understanding — identify which TYPE of clue is present. (4) For any words still unclear, look them up in the dictionary and choose the correct definition for the context. (5) Add at least 8 new words to your personal vocabulary log with: the word, the strategy you used, and the definition. Score yourself: How many could you decode with roots? With context? How many required the dictionary?
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for some action! This is where you get to practice everything we've learned. You'll read those challenging passages, first trying to break down the words with roots, then using the context clues we just talked about, and finally, if you're still stuck, using your dictionary. Make sure to fill up your vocabulary log with at least eight new words and how you figured them out!

slides.text: You now have a complete vocabulary strategy: roots for decoding structure, context clues for refining meaning, and the dictionary for confirming accuracy. This three-step process works for every unfamiliar word you will ever encounter, in any subject, at any level.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify and use all five types of context clues, apply the three-step vocabulary strategy efficiently, and use a dictionary to select the appropriate definition for a given context?
slides.mascot_explanation: Awesome job! This last slide is celebrating that you now have a complete strategy for tackling any tough word you come across, no matter the subject. You've learned to use word parts, the surrounding sentences, and the dictionary as your ultimate vocabulary superpower, and that's going to help you understand so much more when you read!

parent_notes: This lesson completes the vocabulary toolkit: roots, context clues, and dictionary skills. The multi-step strategy teaches children to be strategic and self-sufficient readers who do not give up when they encounter difficult words. The most important habit to develop is trying roots and context BEFORE reaching for the dictionary — this builds independence and speed. Practice at home by occasionally asking 'What do you think that word means?' before defining it for them. The personal vocabulary log is a valuable ongoing resource.

title: Data Analysis — Mean, Median, Mode, and Range
description: Students learn to calculate and interpret measures of central tendency (mean, median, mode) and spread (range). They apply these statistical tools to real-world data sets and discuss which measure is most appropriate for different situations.
instructions:
1. Introduce the concept of summarizing data with a single number.
2. Define and calculate the mean (average): sum of values divided by count.
3. Define and find the median: the middle value when data is ordered.
4. Define and identify the mode: the most frequent value.
5. Define and calculate the range: highest value minus lowest value.
6. Discuss when each measure is most useful and when it can be misleading.
7. Practice with real-world data sets: test scores, temperatures, prices.
8. Examine how outliers affect the mean but not the median.
9. Students collect data and calculate all four measures.
10. Write analytical paragraphs interpreting what the statistics reveal.

slides.heading: Data Analysis
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure into understanding data. It's telling us we're going to learn about four cool ways to describe a bunch of numbers using just one number: the mean, median, mode, and range. Think of it like getting a secret code to unlock what a big list of information really means.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare data sets with varying characteristics: some with outliers, some with clear modes, some with symmetric distributions. Create reference cards defining each statistical measure.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide lists everything we'll need for our data detective work. We've got data sets (those are just lists of numbers we'll be looking at), a calculator to help us crunch numbers, lined paper for writing things down, graph paper for drawing cool charts later, a special reference card with all the definitions, and pencils to do the actual work. Make sure you have all of these ready to go!

slides.text: Data sets can contain hundreds of numbers. We need ways to summarize them. Four key measures: MEAN (average), MEDIAN (middle value), MODE (most common value), and RANGE (spread). Each tells us something different about the data.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, imagine you have a huge list of numbers, like maybe how many points a basketball player scored in every game for a whole season. That's a lot of numbers! This step is telling us that the mean, median, mode, and range are like shortcuts to understand what's typical or how spread out those scores are, without having to look at every single number.

slides.text: MEAN: Add all values, divide by how many there are. Scores: 85, 90, 78, 92, 85. Mean = (85+90+78+92+85)/5 = 430/5 = 86. MEDIAN: Put in order (78, 85, 85, 90, 92) and find the middle. Median = 85. For an even number of values, average the two middle ones.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step shows us how to find two important numbers: the mean and the median. The mean is what most people call the "average" – you just add up all the numbers and then divide by how many numbers there are. The median is the number right in the middle after you put all the numbers in order from smallest to biggest.

slides.text: MODE: The most frequent value. In (78, 85, 85, 90, 92), the mode is 85 (appears twice). A data set can have no mode, one mode, or multiple modes. RANGE: Highest minus lowest. Range = 92 - 78 = 14. Range tells you how spread out the data is.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're learning about the mode and the range. The mode is super easy – it's just the number that shows up the most often in your list. The range is also simple: you find the biggest number and subtract the smallest number from it, which tells you how spread out your data is.

slides.text: CRUCIAL: Outliers distort the mean. Salaries: $30K, $35K, $32K, $28K, $500K. Mean = $125K — misleading! Median = $32K — much more representative. When data has extreme values, the MEDIAN is a better measure of 'typical.' This is why news reports often use median household income, not mean.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a really important point: sometimes, one super-high or super-low number, called an outlier, can really mess with the "average" (the mean). Imagine a millionaire's salary mixed in with everyone else's – the mean would be huge and not show what a typical person earns. In those cases, the median is a much better way to see what's normal.

slides.prompt: Analyze three data sets: (1) Test scores: 88, 92, 76, 95, 88, 82, 90, 88, 84, 79. Calculate mean, median, mode, and range. Which measure best represents a 'typical' score? (2) Home prices: $180K, $210K, $195K, $200K, $185K, $2.1M. Calculate all four measures. Which is most representative and why? (3) Collect your own data: Measure the height (in inches) of 8-10 objects in the room. Calculate all four measures. Create a bar graph of your data. Write an analytical paragraph explaining what the statistics reveal about your data set.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to be data detectives! We'll take these lists of numbers, like test scores or prices, and calculate the mean, median, mode, and range for each. For the test scores, think about which number best shows what a "typical" student scored. Then, we'll even measure some things in our room and do the same thing!

slides.text: Statistics help us understand patterns in data, but they can also mislead if we do not choose the right measure. The next time someone says 'on average,' ask: Which average? Mean or median? Understanding this distinction makes you a more critical consumer of information.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student calculate mean, median, mode, and range accurately, determine which measure is most appropriate for a given data set, and explain how outliers affect different measures?
slides.mascot_explanation: We've learned that these four numbers – mean, median, mode, and range – are powerful tools for understanding data. But remember, they can also be tricky, especially if there are weird numbers in the list. Being able to choose the *right* number to describe data is what makes you a super smart information detective!

parent_notes: Statistical literacy is essential in our data-driven world. The key takeaway is that different measures tell different stories — and choosing the wrong one can be misleading. The home price example (where one mansion distorts the mean) is particularly illuminating. Practice at home by discussing statistics you encounter in news and sports: batting averages, temperature averages, income statistics. Ask 'Which average are they using?' This critical thinking protects against being misled by statistics. These concepts also connect to science (analyzing experimental data) and social studies (understanding demographic data).

title: Climate Change Science — Evidence and Mechanisms
description: Students examine the scientific evidence for climate change and the mechanisms driving it. They analyze temperature data, understand the greenhouse effect, distinguish between natural and human-caused climate factors, and evaluate the scientific consensus.
instructions:
1. Define climate vs. weather: climate is long-term average conditions.
2. Present global temperature data from 1880 to present.
3. Explain the greenhouse effect: how certain gases trap heat in the atmosphere.
4. Identify the main greenhouse gases: CO2, methane, nitrous oxide, water vapor.
5. Discuss natural climate factors: volcanic eruptions, solar cycles, orbital variations.
6. Explain the evidence that current warming is human-caused: rate of change, CO2 correlation, isotope analysis.
7. Discuss the scientific consensus: 97%+ of climate scientists agree on human causation.
8. Examine evidence from multiple sources: ice cores, sea level measurements, satellite data.
9. Students analyze temperature and CO2 graphs and draw conclusions.
10. Discuss the difference between scientific uncertainty and scientific disagreement.

slides.heading: Climate Change Science
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure into climate change science. It's telling us we're going to explore the *evidence* that climate change is happening, the *mechanisms* (that's the science stuff that makes it happen), and how scientists have reached a strong *consensus*, which means they mostly agree on what's going on.

slides.setup_instructions: Print NASA global temperature anomaly graph and atmospheric CO2 graph (Keeling Curve). Prepare greenhouse effect diagram. Print evidence cards describing different lines of evidence for climate change.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this slide is like our science kit for this lesson. You'll need a graph showing how Earth's temperature has changed over time, another graph showing how the amount of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the air has changed, and a diagram that explains something called the "greenhouse effect." We also have some cards with different types of evidence on them and some pencils to write with. Make sure to grab all these materials with a grown-up's help before we start!

slides.text: Weather is what happens today — sunny, rainy, cold. Climate is the average pattern over 30+ years. Climate change means these long-term patterns are shifting. Earth has had natural climate changes before (ice ages, warm periods), but the current change is happening 10 times faster than any natural change in the past 65 million years.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, this step is all about understanding the difference between weather and climate. Think of weather like what you're wearing today – maybe a jacket because it's chilly. Climate is more like your whole wardrobe – all the clothes you have for every season, averaged out over many years. Climate change means those long-term wardrobe patterns, like how warm summers usually are, are starting to shift, and it's happening way faster than it used to.

slides.text: The greenhouse effect: Sunlight passes through the atmosphere and warms Earth's surface. Earth radiates heat back toward space. Greenhouse gases (CO2, methane) trap some of this heat, keeping Earth warm enough for life. WITHOUT the greenhouse effect, Earth would average -18 degrees C (0 degrees F). The problem is that we are ADDING too much CO2, trapping too much heat.
slides.mascot_explanation: This part explains the "greenhouse effect," which is actually a good thing! Imagine Earth wearing a cozy blanket. That blanket is made of certain gases in our atmosphere, like CO2. They trap some of the sun's heat, keeping our planet warm enough for us to live here – without it, Earth would be a frozen ice ball! The problem we're talking about is that we're making that blanket way too thick by adding extra greenhouse gases, trapping too much heat.

slides.text: The evidence is from multiple independent sources: (1) Thermometers show 1.1 degrees C warming since 1880. (2) Ice cores show CO2 levels higher than any time in 800,000 years. (3) Sea levels are rising. (4) Glaciers and ice sheets are shrinking. (5) Ocean temperatures are increasing. All point in the same direction.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here, we're looking at the real proof that our planet's climate is changing. Scientists have gathered information from all sorts of places, like thermometers measuring temperature, ancient ice samples telling us about past air, and even measurements of how much the sea level has risen. All these different clues, like puzzle pieces, are pointing to the same picture: our planet is getting warmer.

slides.text: How do we know it is human-caused? The timing matches industrialization. CO2 from fossil fuels has a distinct carbon isotope signature — scientists can detect it in the atmosphere. Computer models that include human factors match observed warming; models without human factors do not. Over 97% of climate scientists agree.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide tackles the big question: how do we know humans are causing this change? It explains that the timing of the warming lines up with when we started burning lots of fossil fuels, like coal and gas. Scientists can even tell the difference between CO2 from nature and CO2 from burning stuff because it has a special "signature." Plus, computer models that include human activities match what's happening, and scientists who study this stuff overwhelmingly agree it's us.

slides.prompt: Analyze the data: (1) Examine the global temperature graph. Describe the trend in words: What happened from 1880-1940? From 1940-1975? From 1975-present? (2) Examine the CO2 graph (Keeling Curve). How has CO2 concentration changed since 1958? (3) Place the temperature graph next to the CO2 graph. What relationship do you see? Write 3 evidence-based sentences describing the correlation. (4) Review the evidence cards. For each line of evidence, explain in your own words how it supports the conclusion that climate change is happening and is human-caused.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's your turn to be the scientist! You're going to look at those graphs we talked about – the temperature one and the CO2 one – and see what story they tell. Pay attention to how things changed over different time periods, then put them side-by-side to see if they seem connected. After that, read through those evidence cards and explain in your own words how each piece of proof supports the idea that climate change is real and that humans are involved.

slides.text: Science is about following evidence wherever it leads. Multiple independent lines of evidence — temperature records, ice cores, sea levels, satellite data — all point to the same conclusion. Understanding the science empowers you to evaluate claims and make informed decisions.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain the greenhouse effect, identify multiple lines of evidence for climate change, distinguish natural from human factors, and analyze temperature and CO2 data graphs?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide is like a summary and a high-five! It reminds us that science is all about looking at the evidence, and in this case, lots of different kinds of evidence all lead to the same conclusion about climate change. By understanding this science, you're becoming super empowered to figure things out for yourself and make smart choices about our planet's future. You totally rocked looking at all that data and understanding how scientists figure things out!

parent_notes: Climate science can feel overwhelming, but this lesson grounds it in evidence and data analysis. The key message is that climate change is supported by multiple independent lines of evidence, not just one study or one data point. The graph analysis activity develops scientific reasoning — children learn to describe trends, identify correlations, and draw evidence-based conclusions. Avoid making this topic feel hopeless; the next lessons focus on solutions and action. If your child has questions about climate skepticism, discuss the difference between scientific uncertainty about details and the overwhelming consensus about the basic facts.

title: Environmental Art — Creating an Awareness Campaign
description: Students design a visual awareness campaign about an environmental issue, combining graphic design principles, persuasive messaging, and artistic skills. They create posters, infographics, or digital graphics that could be used to educate and motivate their community.
instructions:
1. Study effective awareness campaigns: environmental, health, and social justice examples.
2. Analyze what makes visual campaigns persuasive: strong images, clear messages, emotional appeal.
3. Introduce graphic design principles: hierarchy, contrast, alignment, proximity.
4. Discuss typography: how font choices communicate mood and importance.
5. Students choose an environmental issue for their campaign.
6. Develop a campaign message: one clear, memorable sentence.
7. Create a visual concept: sketch multiple design ideas.
8. Produce the final campaign piece: poster, infographic, or series.
9. Test the campaign on peers: Is the message clear? Is it persuasive?
10. Discuss how art can be a tool for social change.

slides.heading: Environmental Art
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just introducing what we're going to do: create an "Environmental Art" awareness campaign. Think of it like making a poster or a cool graphic to get people thinking and caring about an environmental problem.

slides.setup_instructions: Print examples of effective awareness campaign posters and infographics. Prepare the graphic design principles handout. Have large poster paper and art supplies ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this slide is like our shopping list for our art project. We've got examples of other campaigns to look at, big poster paper to draw on, markers and colored pencils for coloring, rulers for straight lines, and a handout that explains some design tricks. You'll want to grab all these things, maybe with a grown-up's help, so we're ready to create!

slides.text: A visual awareness campaign uses art to change minds and inspire action. The best campaigns have three elements: a POWERFUL IMAGE that grabs attention, a CLEAR MESSAGE that is easy to understand, and a CALL TO ACTION that tells the viewer what to do.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about what makes an awareness campaign really work. It's like a secret recipe: you need a super strong picture that makes people stop and look, a message that's really easy to get, and something that tells people exactly what they can do to help.

slides.text: Graphic design principles: HIERARCHY — make the most important element largest/boldest. CONTRAST — use color and size differences to create visual interest. ALIGNMENT — organize elements in a clean, intentional way. PROXIMITY — group related elements together.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're diving into some cool design secrets that make posters look professional and grab attention. Hierarchy means making the most important thing the biggest or boldest, contrast is about using different colors and sizes to make things pop, alignment is about lining things up neatly, and proximity is about putting related things close together so they make sense.

slides.text: Your campaign message should be ONE clear sentence that people remember. Not: 'Deforestation is a complex issue affecting biodiversity and climate.' But: 'Every minute, we lose a football field of forest.' Simple, vivid, memorable. Then add a call to action: 'Plant a tree. Save a future.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a super important part: your main message needs to be short and punchy, like a slogan you can't forget. Instead of a long explanation, think of something like "Every minute, we lose a football field of forest" – it paints a picture instantly! Then, you need to tell people what they can actually *do*, like "Plant a tree" or "Recycle more."

slides.text: Art has always been a tool for change. During the civil rights movement, posters and images spread the message. Environmental campaigns like 'Reduce, Reuse, Recycle' changed behavior through memorable design. Your campaign could genuinely influence people in your community.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide reminds us that art has always been a powerful way to make big changes. Think about posters for important movements – they helped spread the word and get people involved. Your artwork can do the same thing for the environment, making a real difference in your community.

slides.prompt: Design an environmental awareness campaign: (1) Choose your issue (ocean plastic, deforestation, endangered species, water conservation, air pollution, food waste). (2) Write your campaign message — one memorable sentence. (3) Sketch 3 different visual concepts. (4) Choose the strongest concept and create a finished campaign poster or infographic. Apply graphic design principles: hierarchy, contrast, alignment. Include a powerful image, clear message, and call to action. (5) Test your campaign on a partner: Can they understand the message in 5 seconds? If not, revise for clarity.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is where you get to be the artist and designer! First, pick an environmental issue you care about, then come up with a super short, memorable sentence about it. After that, sketch out three different ideas for how your poster or graphic could look, and then pick the best one to create. Make sure to use those design tricks like hierarchy and contrast we talked about, and don't forget your strong image, clear message, and call to action. Finally, show it to a friend and see if they get it right away!

slides.text: You have just used art as a tool for change. Great campaigns combine artistic skill with clear communication and a passion for the cause. Consider displaying your campaign in a public space — a library, community center, or your school — to actually reach and influence people.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student create a visually effective campaign piece applying graphic design principles, communicate a clear environmental message, and include an actionable call to action?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you just finished creating your own awareness campaign! That's awesome because you used your art skills to try and make people care about something important. If you want to take it even further, you could even display your campaign somewhere people will see it, like at school or in a community center.

parent_notes: Campaign design combines art, persuasive writing, and environmental awareness. The graphic design principles (hierarchy, contrast, alignment) apply to all visual communication and are increasingly important in our visual culture. The '5-second test' (Can someone understand the message in 5 seconds?) teaches clarity and audience awareness. If your child creates a strong campaign piece, consider actually displaying it — a library, community board, or social media post. Knowing their art can reach real people is powerfully motivating.

title: Sustainable Living — Energy Audit and Conservation Plan
description: Students conduct a home energy audit, identifying where energy is used and wasted. They learn about different energy sources, calculate energy costs, and create a practical energy conservation plan that can save money while reducing environmental impact.
instructions:
1. Discuss where household energy comes from: electricity, natural gas, heating oil.
2. Explain how electricity is generated: fossil fuels, nuclear, renewable sources.
3. Introduce the concept of an energy audit: systematically checking energy use.
4. Walk through common energy waste: phantom loads, inefficient lighting, poor insulation.
5. Demonstrate reading an electricity meter or utility bill.
6. Calculate energy costs for common appliances: watts x hours x rate.
7. Students complete a home energy audit checklist.
8. Identify the biggest energy savings opportunities.
9. Create a family energy conservation plan with measurable goals.
10. Calculate potential cost savings from the plan.

slides.heading: Sustainable Living
slides.subheading: Home Energy Audit and Conservation Plan
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this first slide is like the title page for our adventure! It's introducing the whole topic: "Sustainable Living," which basically means living in a way that's good for the planet and doesn't use up all our resources. The subtitle tells us exactly what we'll be focusing on: doing a "Home Energy Audit" to find out where we use energy at home, and then making a "Conservation Plan" to save energy and money.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a comprehensive energy audit checklist covering lighting, heating/cooling, appliances, electronics, and insulation. Obtain a sample utility bill to analyze. Create a conservation plan template.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is showing us all the tools we'll need for our energy mission. We've got an "Energy audit checklist" to help us look for energy waste, a "Sample utility bill" so we can see what real energy bills look like, and a "Calculator" to do some math. We also have a "Conservation plan template" to write down our ideas, plus "Pencils" and "Lined paper" for taking notes. Make sure you have these ready, maybe ask a grown-up to help you gather them!

slides.text: The average American household spends over $2,000 per year on energy. About 30% of that energy is WASTED — through phantom loads (devices using power when 'off'), inefficient lighting, poor insulation, and unnecessary use. An energy audit identifies these waste points.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, this is a super important fact to get us started: did you know most families spend a LOT of money on energy every year, and a big chunk of that is just wasted? This slide explains that about 30% of the energy we pay for just disappears into thin air – things like electronics that are plugged in but not even being used, lights left on in empty rooms, or heat escaping through leaky windows. Our goal today is to figure out exactly where that wasted energy is going in our own homes.

slides.text: How to calculate energy cost: Find the wattage of a device (on its label). Multiply by hours used per day. Divide by 1,000 to convert to kilowatt-hours (kWh). Multiply by the electricity rate (about $0.12-0.15 per kWh). Example: A 60-watt bulb on for 8 hours = 0.48 kWh = about $0.06 per day.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide shows us how to do some cool math to figure out how much our appliances actually cost to run. It's like a recipe: you find out how much power a device uses (called wattage), see how long you use it each day, and then multiply it all out. This helps us understand which things are costing us the most money, so we know where to focus our energy-saving efforts.

slides.text: Phantom loads are sneaky: a phone charger plugged in but not charging still draws power. A TV on standby uses power 24/7. A game console in 'sleep' mode uses power continuously. These small loads add up to 5-10% of household electricity use.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to meet the energy vampires! This slide is all about "phantom loads," which are devices that secretly suck up electricity even when they're turned "off" or just sitting there. Think about phone chargers, TVs on standby, or game consoles in sleep mode – they're always using a little bit of power, and when you add it all up, it can be a surprisingly big chunk of your electricity bill!

slides.text: Quick wins for energy conservation: Switch to LED bulbs (use 75% less energy). Unplug chargers when not in use. Use power strips to eliminate phantom loads. Adjust the thermostat 2 degrees (save 3% per degree). Wash clothes in cold water. Air dry when possible.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the fun part where we learn some easy tricks to save energy! It's like finding "quick wins" for your home. Things like switching to super-efficient LED light bulbs, unplugging things you're not using, or even just turning the thermostat down a tiny bit can make a big difference. It shows us that saving energy doesn't have to be hard; it can be as simple as changing a few habits.

slides.prompt: Conduct an energy audit: (1) Complete the energy audit checklist, going room by room through your home. Check for: lights left on in empty rooms, devices on standby, thermostat settings, window/door drafts, and phantom loads. (2) Calculate the daily energy cost of 5 common appliances in your home using the wattage formula. (3) Create a family energy conservation plan with at least 8 specific actions. For each, estimate the monthly savings. Total your projected annual savings. (4) Make a pledge poster with your top 5 conservation commitments.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is where you become an energy detective! Your mission is to go through your house and use that checklist to find all the places energy might be wasted, like checking for lights left on or drafts from windows. Then, you'll use the math from earlier to figure out how much some of your favorite appliances cost to run, and finally, you'll create a plan with your family on how to save energy, writing down at least eight specific actions.

slides.text: Energy conservation is the fastest, cheapest way to reduce your environmental footprint AND save money. The energy audit skills you learned today are used by professional energy consultants. Share your conservation plan with your family and track your electricity usage over the next month to see the impact.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify common energy waste sources, calculate energy costs using the wattage formula, and create a specific, measurable energy conservation plan?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide wraps it all up and reminds us why this is so awesome. Saving energy is like a superpower – it helps the planet by reducing pollution, and it also puts more money back into your family's pocket. You've learned how to spot energy waste, calculate costs, and make a real plan, just like the pros do! Now, go share your plan with your family and see how much energy you can save together!

parent_notes: This lesson combines environmental science with financial literacy and practical math. The energy cost calculations reinforce multiplication and division skills while teaching real-world application. Complete the energy audit together as a family — it often reveals surprising waste. Tracking your electricity bill over the following months provides measurable feedback on conservation efforts. The phantom load concept is eye-opening — many families discover they waste significant energy on devices they thought were 'off.' Consider making the conservation plan a family project with a shared savings goal.

title: Literary Criticism — Character Development and Arc
description: Students analyze how characters change over the course of a novel, examining the internal and external forces that drive character development. They track Esperanza's transformation using evidence from across the novel and write a character analysis essay.
instructions:
1. Define character arc: the transformation a character undergoes throughout a story.
2. Distinguish between static characters (unchanged) and dynamic characters (transformed).
3. Discuss the forces that drive change: external events and internal realizations.
4. Map Esperanza's character arc from Chapter 1 to the current chapter.
5. Identify the key turning points that shifted her perspective.
6. Examine how other characters serve as mirrors and foils for Esperanza.
7. Discuss what 'rising' means metaphorically — what is Esperanza rising from and toward?
8. Students create a character arc diagram with evidence.
9. Write a character analysis essay tracing Esperanza's transformation.
10. Peer review focusing on textual evidence and analytical depth.

slides.heading: Literary Criticism
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide just introduces what we're diving into: something called "Literary Criticism," which is basically a fancy way of saying we're going to be super-detectives, looking closely at a book to figure out how and why characters change. We'll focus on "Character Development and Arc," which means tracking how a character transforms throughout a story.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare character arc diagram templates with a rising line graph structure. Print character analysis essay templates with sections for introduction, body paragraphs, and conclusion. Have all previous reading journals available for evidence gathering.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is like our toolkit for the lesson! You'll need the book *Esperanza Rising* to find all the details, and then we have some templates: one for a "character arc diagram," which is like a roadmap of Esperanza's journey, and another for a "character analysis essay" where we'll write down our findings. Your reading journals are super important because they're full of notes and quotes we can use as proof, and then you'll use highlighters, paper, and pencils to get it all done.

slides.text: A character ARC is the path of change a character follows from beginning to end. Dynamic characters are transformed by their experiences. Static characters remain the same. In great literature, the protagonist's arc IS the story — the external plot drives internal change.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, what we're looking at here is the definition of a "character arc." Think of it like a roller coaster ride for a character – they start somewhere, go through ups and downs, and end up in a totally different place. Characters who change a lot are called "dynamic," and those who stay pretty much the same are "static." In *Esperanza Rising*, the main character's big changes are what the whole story is really about.

slides.text: Esperanza's arc: Chapter 1 — wealthy, sheltered, unaware of others' struggles. Her father's death and flight to California shatter her world. In the camp, she learns humility, empathy, and resilience. Key turning points: arriving at the camp, doing manual labor, Mama's illness, the strike.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is giving us a sneak peek at Esperanza's actual journey! She starts off living a super fancy life, completely unaware of how tough things can be for others. But after her dad dies and she has to move to California, her whole world gets flipped upside down, and she has to learn to be strong and care about people who aren't like her anymore. We'll be looking at moments like arriving at the camp and when her mom gets sick as big turning points for her.

slides.text: FOIL characters highlight the protagonist's traits through contrast. Miguel is a foil for Esperanza: both face hardship, but Miguel has always been a worker while Esperanza is learning. Marta is another foil: she channels her frustration into activism while Esperanza focuses on family survival.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here, we're talking about "foil" characters. Imagine you have a flashlight; a foil character is like a mirror that helps you see the main character's qualities more clearly by being different.
